Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Investigating Sulfur Sources and Sulfate Oxidation Chemistry in New Zealand Aerosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sulfate aerosols are a critical part of climate change, the water cycle, and significantly impact human health, yet we do not completely understand the sources of sulfur, nor how it is oxidized into sulfate in the atmosphere. In order to study the impact of sulfur in the environment, researchers in collaboration with the Institute of Geological and Nuclear Science (GNS) will collect aerosols at Baring Head, located on the southern tip of the North Island of New Zealand. In contrast to the Northern Hemisphere, where man-made sulfur dominates, the majority of Southern Hemisphere sulfur is from natural sources and of marine origin. Many Baring Head aerosols are of marine origin, which allows researchers to assess marine sulfur chemistry without terrestrial influences. In addition to the unique sampling location, GNS possesses the experience, expertise, and analytical capability required for evaluating the sulfur chemistry in this project.

To assess sulfur chemistry, researchers will utilize the stable isotope concentrations of sulfur (d34S) and oxygen (d17O, d18O, D17O) to evaluate sources and oxidation pathways. Sulfur isotopes allow for the differentiation of sulfur sources (low d34S for land sources; elevated d34S for marine sources), as the value of d34S is retained during oxidation. Oxygen isotopes provide insight to the oxidation pathways (gas phase oxidation, D17O = 0; aqueous phase oxidation, D17O > 0) that form sulfate. Additionally, by collecting size segregated aerosols, researchers will be able to analyze gas and aqueous phase oxidation of a comparable air mass. Coarser aerosols are more likely to undergo aqueous phase oxidation than the finer fraction, as sea water in this region is slightly more alkaline thus promoting aqueous oxidation. Once combined, the analyses preformed will create a robust data set that will compliment future modeling projects and enhance the understanding of the impact sulfate aerosols have on climate change, the water cycle, and human health worldwide. This award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since particulate matter plays an important role in climate change, the hydrologic cycle, and human health, understanding their sources and oxidation pathways is crucial. Understanding sources of sulfate, an important components of PM, is important for gauging air quality, identifying issues, and creating mitigation strategies. The primary focus of this project was to compare and contrast particulate matter sampled in an urban environment against particulate matter of pristine marine origin. By assessing the sources of sulfur and evaluating the oxidation pathways utilized in the formation of sulfate, we hope to expand the understanding of sulfur cycling. A year-long sampling campaign was set up at Baring Head Atmospheric Research Station in June 2015. The campaign will utilize two samplers with size segregation ability to separate the coarse and fine fractions, as we expect the chemistry to be different in each fraction. One of these samplers will collect only marine particulates (by sampling only southerly wind events) and the other will sample continuously. Although the campaign is still ongoing, we are set to start analysis on filters collected thus far within the next month.

The sampling campaign at Baring Head was set up to compliment a study conducted in Whangarei, New Zealand, a coastal city located near the top of the North Island. Whangarei provided a unique opportunity to analyze a complex mixture of sources, such as shipping emissions, biomass burning, motor vehicles, industrial emissions, geothermal emissions, and coastal influences. Analysis of our Whangarei samples confirmed a heavy influence from urban sources, but also showed some natural sourcing. There was significant marine input as well, which was expected due to the sampler’s close proximity to the harbor and ocean. The analysis of sulfur is currently planned, but expected to show both natural and urban influence.

During EAPSI, our collaboration was expanded to incorporate New Zealand’s National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA), which has helped the project in many ways.  The Baring Head Atmospheric Research Station, where the sampling campaign is being conducted, is operated by NIWA. As a result, NIWA scientists working at the station will collect and change out the filters during the campaign. Mike Harvey, my main collaborator at NIWA also provided campaign design guidance and construction support during set up, as well as access to NIWA’s climate database in order to retrieve meteorological readings to support the data sets.

Data obtained from both Whangarei and Baring Head will provide new insight to Southern Hemisphere sulfur cycling, and will compliment modeling studies. In addition, data could provide insight as to how aerosols/particulate matter impact climate and the hydrological cycle. Information obtain could also support research into the impact that particulate matter has on human health. On a local or regional scale, this data set could contribute to environmental policy. However, as analysis and collection are still being conducted, it is difficult to determine the full usefulness of this data set. At the very least, data obtained would be able to support or test climate models.
